children.name: Introduction
children.content:
The workshop results show that materiality played a central role in
helping participants perceive, express, organise, and share their
experiences of UTIs. Introduced as physical properties such as texture,
weight, shape, and sharpness, the variables developed into more than
simple descriptors, becoming tools through which participants translated
bodily sensations into forms that others could understand and engage
with.

This aligns closely with the core aim of the research, which is to
strengthen the perception and communication of UTI symptoms in women by
centring their lived experience as a form of knowledge. Medical practice
often prioritises measurable indicators, leaving many aspects of bodily
experience unaddressed or undervalued. The participatory process
developed in this study responds to this gap by combining autographic
design and data physicalization to explore how subjective sensations can
be materialised, made visible, and shared. Through material engagement,
participants produced artefacts that reflected their individual
experiences while also functioning as shared elements of reference
within group discussion and clinical dialogue. Physical variables
provided a structure that linked personal sensation to perceptible
qualities with relevance for healthcare, enabling embodied experiences
to be articulated in communicable forms.

Initially conceived as design components, physical variables took on a
conceptual role during the workshops. Rather than operating as neutral
encodings, they acted as generative elements that shaped interpretation
and supported the production of meaning. The following discussion
examines how this shift occurs through participation, material
engagement, and evolving practices of measurement. This leads to the
next chapter (7), where the physical variable apparatus is introduced as
an analytical and participatory tool for structuring and interpreting
embodied data across different contexts.

children.name: 6.1 Participatory mapping for collective knowledge
children.content:
In the context of data representation, and data visualization in
particular, mapping refers to the process through which data is
translated into visual form by establishing deliberate correspondences
between data attributes and visual variables. This process assigns
aspects of a dataset to elements such as position, colour, size,
texture, or movement, enabling viewers to perceive, compare, and
interpret patterns. Mapping never functions as a neutral technical step.
Choices around encoding reflect situated decisions shaped by context,
purpose, and audience, which influence what becomes legible and what
remains obscured. Foundational work by Bertin (1983) outlines the core
visual variables at the centre of mapping, while Munzner (2014) and Ware
(2021) extend this understanding to perceptual and cognitive principles
that guide effective encodings. Through the concept of autographic
design, Offenhuber (2023) shows how mapping also operates within
physical and material visualizations, where data is articulated through
embodied, tactile, and situated forms. Mapping therefore operates both
as a design decision and as a knowledge practice, shaping how
understanding is produced through the act of representation.

Within this study, mapping is approached as a participatory, cognitive,
and social act. Participants do not only locate symptoms on the body but
also articulated relations among sensations, materials, and meanings.
These relations form a network of correspondences that supports the
recognition of patterns across experiences. By working together to map
sensations onto physical variables, individuals moved from personal
expression toward forms of shared understanding. The group environment
encouraged negotiation and reflection, transforming accounts of
discomfort or pain into artefacts that others could perceive and
compare.

The collective discussion of symptoms revealed differences in
perception, vocabulary, and experience. Rather than dissolving these
differences, the mapping process made them productive. Negotiation
around terms such as pain, burning, or pressure demonstrated that
ambiguity is informative. Ambiguity indicates the boundaries of what can
be described and highlights nuances that biomedical language tends to
overlook. As participants compared their sensations and explore how
these might relate to one another, subjective experiences became
recognisable as shared and relational phenomena rather than isolated
individual conditions.

This capacity to connect personal accounts with broader social and
cultural contexts recalls Wright Mills’ concept of the sociological
imagination (1959). Mills argued that personal troubles are inseparable
from public issues and that understanding emerges when individuals
perceive how their experiences relate to collective conditions. In the
workshops, participants recognised aspects of their own symptoms in the
shared expressions of others, translating private sensations into forms
of collective meaning. Recent work on data imagination by Pangrazio and
Selwyn (2023) extends this idea to contemporary data practices. They
suggest that people make sense of their data by imagining how it relates
to wider social and technological structures. In this study,
participatory mapping encouraged a similar form of imagination.
Participants treated their sensations as data to be reflected upon and
reshaped, exploring how these could be understood in relation to others
and to broader cultural framings of health and illness.

Participation therefore operates as both a process and a method of
generating knowledge. Through participation, personal sensations become
part of a shared enquiry. Experiences that might otherwise remain
private are expressed, compared, and discussed with others. The workshop
becomes a setting where knowledge is not only exchanged but created. As
people work with materials and respond to one another’s interpretations,
knowledge emerges through interaction, negotiation, and mutual
recognition. This participatory form of mapping anchors individual
experience within a collective space of understanding, expanding the
vocabulary through which illness can be perceived and communicated.

children.name: Introduction
children.content:
Material engagement played a central role in the emergence of meaning
during the workshops. Through tactile and spatial interaction,
participants accessed sensations that were otherwise difficult to
express in words. Manipulating, shaping, and combining materials
encouraged reflection on the intensity, duration, and quality of their
symptoms, while the process itself introduced a temporal dimension to
how these experiences were interpreted and understood. The following
sections expand on how this knowledge developed and the conditions that
shaped its emergence.

children.name: 6.2.1 The role of gestures
children.content:
The gestures performed with materials acted as a way of thinking through
the body. As participants pressed, connected, and layered components,
they examined how the physical qualities of matter relate to their
bodily sensations. These actions invited observation and comparison,
prompting participants to reflect on how different materials could
express what they feel. Through this process, the materials take on an
active role, guiding attention and shaping interpretation. Rather than
serving as passive tools, they influenced how participants reasoned and
communicate about their experiences. This dynamic recalls Schön’s notion
of a “conversation with materials,” where reflection arises from the
feedback that materials provide during manipulation (1983). In this
context, making became a process of enquiry in which touching,
arranging, and adjusting materials generated new insights into how
sensations are perceived and shared.

children.name: 6.2.2 Material un-literacy as a condition for knowledge generation
children.content:
The use of physical materials expanded the perceptual range available to
participants, offering richer and more diverse stimuli than purely
visual representations. Variations in texture, weight, and affordance
encouraged reflection and comparison, supporting the articulation of
sensations that are often difficult to express verbally. This
multiplicity of sensory elements helped participants refine bodily
awareness and connect perception with interpretation.

Some participants showed limited familiarity with material properties,
which at times made interpretation more complex but also more
generative. Uncertainty about how to describe or make sense of material
qualities prompted discussion and negotiation, as participants worked to
construct shared meanings rather than rely on established symbolic
conventions. This absence of predefined references became a productive
condition that encouraged collective reasoning and experimentation. A
more familiar visual vocabulary might have enabled quicker recognition,
but it would likely have reduced opportunities for reflection and
dialogue.

children.name: 6.2.3 Material specificity to expand interpretation
children.content:
The empirical results show that meaning does not reside in materials
themselves but emerges through the interactions they sustain. Even
though the selection of materials available during the workshops was
limited, the specificity of each material provided perceptual cues that
supported richer and more nuanced insights. Foam, wood, and polyester
acted as mediators between inner perception and shared expression,
offering tangible ways to embody sensations such as resistance,
pressure, or relief. Their varied textures, densities, and weights
expanded the vocabulary available to participants and supported the
recognition of differences among symptoms while fostering empathy within
the group.

Material specificity worked in two directions. On one side, it helped
participants identify sensations that aligned with the qualities of the
materials. On the other side, it made them aware of aspects of their
experience that could not be fully expressed through those same
materials. The gap between what a material afforded and what a sensation
required encouraged participants to elaborate and refine their
interpretations. This movement between adequacy and inadequacy became a
source of insight. The limits of representation prompted further
explanation, comparison, and negotiation, creating opportunities for
reflection that would have been less present with more familiar or
symbolically fixed forms.

The connections that emerged during the workshops were dynamic rather
than predetermined. They were shaped through discussion and through the
actions participants performed with the materials and continued to
evolve across sessions. The process did not rely on stable codes but
encouraged flexible and situated interpretations that reveal how people
collectively reason about their bodies. The materials served as shared
reference points that supported conversation while remaining open to
multiple meanings and configurations.

By transforming bodily sensations into tangible artefacts, participants
used materials to explore and communicate their experiences. These
artefacts were not final outputs but visible traces of an ongoing
process of reflection and dialogue. The materials encouraged attention,
comparison, and conversation, turning abstract sensations into forms
that could be seen, touched, and shared. Working with materials helped
participants notice, question, and refine how they understood their
symptoms, showing that understanding emerges not only through words but
also through the interactions between people, materials, and the actions
performed together.

children.name: 6.2.4 Metaphor as an extension of material meaning
children.content:
When certain variables could not find direct correspondence in the
available materials, participants turned to imagination and metaphor to
bridge the gap. Physical properties such as temperature, movement, or
internal sensations were not always perceptible through the materials
provided, yet participants reinterpreted them symbolically. Wood was
described as “warm,” while polystyrene was perceived as “cold,” even
though both shared a similar temperature. These reinterpretations show
how the limitations of materials can become productive triggers for
creative reasoning. The absence of perfect correspondence encouraged
participants to project sensory and emotional qualities onto matter,
transforming restriction into opportunity. This process parallels the
function of metaphor in language, where abstract or complex experiences
are made understandable through association. By extending meaning beyond
direct sensory evidence, participants demonstrated that material
constraints can stimulate imagination and open new pathways for
knowledge generation through the interaction of perception,
interpretation, and creativity.

children.name: 6.3 Reframing measurement and validity
children.content:
The introduction of physical variables redefines how measurement and
validity can be understood in healthcare research. Conventional
biomedical approaches value precision and reproducibility and rely on
quantifiable indicators that can be compared across contexts. These
approaches often reduce measurement to numerical references treated as
neutral recordings of pre-determined information. Such practices
privilege abstraction and detachment, overlooking the interpretive and
embodied dimensions that shape how people perceive and communicate their
conditions.

Physical variables challenge this view by presenting data collection as
a situated and material process through which meaning is generated
rather than merely recorded. This reframing shifts attention from
abstraction to experience and turns the act of measurement into an
interpretive process that links sensation, perception, and
communication.

Recent discussions on measurement emphasise this relational feature.
Every act of measuring involves choices about what is considered
relevant and how meaning is assigned to what is observed. These
decisions are shaped by the context in which measurement occurs and by
the people and tools involved (Mari et al., 2023). From this
perspective, a measure is not a neutral record but the outcome of a
relationship between observer, instrument, and situation. Validity
therefore depends not only on precision but on how well a measure
reflects the conditions from which it emerges and how effectively it
communicates meaning to those who engage with it.

Reframing measurement through materiality extends this relational
understanding into embodied and participatory practice. When measurement
occurs through material engagement, observation and interpretation
become inseparable from the act of making. Meaning arises through the
relationship established among participants, materials, and contexts
rather than through detached observation.

In this perspective, evidence emerges within the process rather than
existing prior to it. Each artefact and exchange functions as both data
and interpretation, showing how participants negotiate and share their
experiences through material engagement. The validity of the results
depends on the resonance they produce, understood as the extent to which
outcomes reflect lived experience and support meaningful connections
among participants and experts.

This reframing also reshapes the role of the researcher. Acting as a
facilitator situates the researcher within the dynamics of
meaning-making rather than outside them. The role involves creating
conditions in which participants can express, compare, and reflect on
their experiences while attending to the evolving relationships within
the group. Medical experts contribute by linking experiential accounts
with clinical perspectives, ensuring that insights generated through
material engagement complement, rather than contradict, established
medical understanding.

The quality of the research depends on openness, transparency, and
ethical attention rather than control and reproducibility. Meaning
develops through interaction, dialogue, and continuous reflection.
Within this participatory setting, physical variables coexist with
biomedical measures, enriching them by making visible the relational and
qualitative aspects of health, bringing forward what is felt, and
opening possibilities for dialogue between different forms of knowledge.

children.name: 6.4 Physical variables as an onto-epistemology contribution
children.content:
Building on this understanding of measurement, physical variables extend
the shift from recording to generating meaning. They function not only
as methodological tools but as onto-epistemological agents that
participate in the creation of knowledge. Rather than capturing
pre-existing information, physical variables support processes in which
meaning emerges through situated engagement. Their use transforms data
collection into an experiential practice that links sensation,
perception, and communication through material interaction.

This perspective aligns with Barad’s agential realism (2007), which
conceptualises measurement as a practice that brings phenomena into
being rather than simply revealing them. In this view, knowing and being
are inseparable, and reality is shaped by material arrangements that
define what can be observed. Applying this approach to physical
variables reframes them as active contributors to the production of
knowledge. They do not merely express what participants already know,
but participate in shaping how experiences take form and become
shareable.

When a participant selects a rough surface to express burning pain or
chooses a fragile form to convey vulnerability, the material does more
than illustrate the symptom. The physical properties actively shape how
the sensation is perceived, both by the participant and by others. The
material becomes part of the interpretation, influencing how the symptom
is felt, understood, and communicated. Through this process, a private
bodily experience becomes materially present and available for
collective reflection. Understanding emerges not from detached
observation but from the intra-actions among participants, materials,
and the unfolding situation.

Barad’s concept of intra-action clarifies this dynamic (2007). Entities
do not pre-exist their relations; they arise through them. In this
research, physical variables gain meaning only through the relations
established among bodies, materials, and the interpretations negotiated
within the group. Their significance is therefore situated and fluid and
reflects the specific conditions of the workshop rather than a fixed set
of properties. Each variable carries traces of the decisions,
comparisons, and conversations through which it emerged.

Diffraction adds another layer to this understanding by emphasising that
knowledge arises not from eliminating differences but from engaging with
them. Physical variables support this approach by allowing participants
to express diverse and sometimes conflicting experiences while still
revealing areas of resonance. Two participants may use different
materials to represent pain, yet their explanations can highlight shared
qualities of the experience. This capacity to hold differences while
examining their connections creates a form of understanding grounded in
the specific circumstances of each contribution rather than in
abstraction.

In this way, physical variables contribute on two interconnected levels.
As methodological tools, they help participants articulate and share
embodied experiences that are often difficult to express verbally. As
epistemic artefacts, they materialise the collective processes through
which symptoms are interpreted, negotiated, and understood. Their dual
role challenges conventional views of data as detached and fixed,
showing instead how knowledge in healthcare can be generated through
participatory, embodied, and materially grounded practices.

children.name: 6.5 From discussion to the apparatus
children.content:
This discussion shows how the study redefines knowledge production
through participation and material engagement. Participatory mapping
supportes the articulation of individual sensations within a shared
environment, and interactions with materials created conditions for
reflection and collective interpretation. The reframing of measurement
further grounded validity in relational and contextual resonance rather
than numerical precision.

Together, these dimensions illustrate how knowledge in healthcare can
emerge through the interplay of bodies, materials, and discourse. The
co-creation of artefacts made symptoms visible not as fixed signs of
disease but as evolving expressions shaped by perception, language, and
material feedback. By presenting data as situated and interpretive, the
study aligns with a broader shift in design research that focuses less
on producing representations and more on shaping the processes through
which knowledge is generated.

The next chapter builds on these insights by introducing the physical
variable apparatus. In this thesis, the apparatus is conceived as a
material–discursive arrangement that connects participation,
materiality, and interpretation. Drawing on Barad’s notion of apparatus
as the configuration through which phenomena become knowable, it
formalises the conditions that enable embodied experience to be
elicited, articulated, and shared, transforming the conceptual
foundations of the research into a practical system that structures
participatory enquiry and supports the generation of situated and
collective knowledge in healthcare and related contexts.
